reviewText:
I read a lot of reviews on Disciples III.  A lot were bad however there was a lot of positive as well so I took a chance because I loved Disciples 2 so much.  Well let me be another that is in the bad review camp.
I also read that D3-Resurrection was the game that should of been released in the first place.  They said they fixed most of the bugs.  If that is true then I would hate to play the hot mess that was before this one because there is still tons of bugs.   Some of those same reviews said how beautiful the graphics were, are they playing the same game as me?  Your move points are very low, so just going to get that gold pile that is about 5 inches away takes two turns. Its also really hard to logically see where you can move on the map without triggering combat.   Sometimes during combat there is no walking animation, the units just glide as they move.  Most of the time when an archer fires the terrain will block the camera view. Really cheesy!   The combat is slow, repetitive and boring.  The only real tactical dission is what unit to attack.  Then it boils down to just exchanging blows and hope you can win.
I dont recommend Disciples III.  If interested get Disciples 2 as that is the game the fans fell in love with.
voteText: 46 of 59 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Bugs, bugs, bugs everywhere. The basics of the game are good, but the overwhelming flow of bugs keep the fun out of reach. The game stile of this 3rd chapter of the series has changed a lot, you may enjoy, you may not; but the realy is... it doesnt matter. Sooooo many and anoying bugs can make you hate the game. For real.
voteText: 41 of 53 people (77%) found this review helpful

reviewText: *edit for more details to help people make decisions*\nAt one point, kalypso changed the login procedure associated with this game where we suddenly had to register on their sites to actually play the game. At that point, i entered my key and managed to play a few hours. Those hours were not incredibly fun. The strategy would boil down in having werewolves as soon as possible because all the melee creatures were unable to touch them making most fights trivial.\nThe features they had changed from renaissance didnt look like good ideas balance wise so i ended up quitting the game. Fast forward 5 months and i suddenly cannot login the game anymore because it decided that my online key isn't valid. Nothing has changed in my setup. Since the game wasn't super fun last time around, i gave up. Couldn't recommend the game to anyone because of both the balance issues and the key issues on their server.

reviewText:
Overall if you enjoyed Renaissance and don't have Reincarnation, it might be worth having this on sale.
Otherwise, just get Reincarnation.

+Continues story from III Renaissance
+Same graphics/gameplay, familiar and enjoyable if you enjoyed Renaissance
+New race to play as the Undead
+Length of story comparable to Renaissance

-Extra DRM: Kalypso account required
-Similar problems to Renaissance
-Esc key for menu and right-click info only work intermittently
-No subtitles in voiced cutscenes
-No voiceovers in text dialogue
-Little in the way of new gameplay elements, only 1 playable race

reviewText: Not as good as disciples II but I would still recommend it for any disciples fan. I think the game was made a little dummer this time but the graphics are better. Story line will put you to sleep. Every map features a lot of objectives. Huge maps to explore. more advanced combat from the one we saw in disciples 2. Here both parties actually can move around during fight which is both good and bad. If a melee unit gets close to your ranged unit it will take heavy damage. If you take out enemy unit that has healing properties you will gain advantage.

reviewText: A disappointing addition to one of my favorite fantasy series. Poor AI, questionable design decisions, and a surprising lack of challenge mar the venerable Disciples pedigree. Truth is, everything that is novel about Disciples III was already in Disciples II, and the new stuff is basically a retread of features from other games.

reviewText: Terrible. This is a good exercise in how to not make a game. It barely works, it's not fun to play, and there's tons of logical failures; they assume you understand the interface and don't tell you that you need to right click to get to a lot of the options.

reviewText: Ouch, it really pains me to see that a title with such a rich and interesting history (Gallean series) suffered so much after the transition to hexagon open battlefield. The developers apparently thought that all you need to do is leave everything as it was in the previous games. The reality proved them wrong. The result is a bug-riddled game where gameplay is not fun (stupid AI) and full of unbalanced creatures. Okay, the game looks beautiful and is full of the series folklore, but nowadays graphics is not enough for a decent game. There is much unused potential in the title. But I don't recommend it in the current state. I hope they change the dev team and truly ressurect the title.

reviewText:
I lot of people seem to be having difficulty in the first act.  The trick is that you need to save gold to buy units that you can spawn in battle.  I recommend trenant and guardian.  Then you need to research werewolfs asap and 1 & 2 nd acts will be a breeze.

This game IS good as long as you have the right approach and do not get put off by hard difficulty at first.
The storyline is also interesting.  I am about to finish the game and I actually look forward to the ending

reviewText:
Disciples III: Resurrection – a grand sequel of the series!

This is a new landmark in the history of Nevendaar, when a new race ascends to power – the ruthless and merciless Undead Hordes. It is the story of selfless love and unfading glory. Heroes of the past, who had lost their lives, but not their sentience, are exacting their revenge in the name of Mortis, the Goddess of Death.

This Disciples 3 game is dedicated to a new race – the Undead Hordes. It was the mostly anticipated race among the gamers and fans of the Disciples series, and now their dreams have come true.

reviewText:
Modelled after the game format used in Heroes of Might and Magic, and improved upon hugely, Disciples is an engrossing game to play once you've mastered the rather steep learning curve involved.  There are two different types of magic, one for use in the battle arenas, and one for use whilst travelling across the world map, and if you don't have your wits about you, neither will make sense.  Apart from that the game unfolds nicely (play the main release first, as this is the expansion, even though it plays without the original) and has an involving, if very complicated, storyline.

Watch out for crashes and other curruptions even in the updated version.  Always save before going to battle or visiting shops as these tend to create crash points.

They've made changes to the combat system in this exapnsion, and personally I don't think they're for the better.  Certain character types (mellee in particulart) now have two slots per battle round, rather than just one, and reinsert themselves high up the turn table when their first turn has been used.  This may have been done to balance the difficulty that mellee types normally missed their first round attack as they couldn't cover enough arena squares to reach an enemy.  However, mellee types have always had the extra advantage of delivering much more damage than a ranged attack, so this change really wasn't necessary.  It actually becomes confusing.  That, coupled with a revised cover shot" system
date: whereby you get locked into covering yourself
recommended: not just other characters under your control
hoursPlayed: means the balance of arena battles has been seriouslly jarred and takes a while to figure things out.  You can also trap oppsition units into self-cover
voteText: so perhasps there is a small up side to this.  Like a lot of games
helpfulPercent: once you'be worked out the system you can play it to your advantage
votesHelpful: but it's a tricky system and misjudgements are usually fatal.\n\nOn the plus side
votesTotal: Lambert has been brought back from what we thought was the dead
